text.p: These are the leading stories in the Albanian press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
KOHA JONE
- Editorial says President Sali Berisha has launched a ghost electoral campaign while opposition parties still hesitate over participating in upcoming elections.
- An interview with Vlore residents says two people shot dead on Monday were allegedly killed by the Shik secret police.
- Germany holds the Democratic Party and Berisha responsible for the deadlock over the electoral law.
- Local currency lek is losing ground against the dollar which is quoted at 160 leks, up from 155 last week.

- Two-page interview with Bashkim Driza, boss of the Populli investment scheme that collapsed in January, accusing former Prime Minister Aleksander Meksi of stealing $20 million from Populli to cover the budget deficit.
ALBANIA
- Leftist parties are scared they might fail to enter the next parliament.
- The Kardhiqi bridge linking Gjirokaster with the rest of the country was rocked by a strong explosion. Specialists say that the movement of trucks is impossible.
- President Sali Berisha remains the backbone of the Democratic Party and will help it to win the June 29 elections, party leader Ylli Vejsiu said.
- Rightest parties will share more than 70 percent of seats in the next parliament, Berisha told a crowd of Democratic Party supporters in Shijak town on Sunday.
GAZETA SHQIPTARE
- Political parties have yet to agree on the electoral law. The south is plunged into violence and anarchy.
- Berisha said he would not decree opposition amendments on the new election law passed by the Democrat-dominated parliament.
- Social Democratic Party has threatened to withdraw from national reconciliation government unless Berisha's Democratic Party includes opposition opinion in the electoral law.
RILINDJA DEMOKRATIKE
- President Sali Berisha accused Finance Minister Arben Malaj of blocking transparency on pyramid investment schemes.
- The winter of communist rebellion is over, the spring of democracy has come, paper says blaming the Socialist Party for the violence and chaos which hit Albania in February.
ZERI I POPULLIT
- Paper alleges that criminal bands roaming the country are the armed wing of Democratic Party and Shik.
- "Down with Berisha" and "We want our money back" people cried out in Kurbin as the Albanian President was about to adress an electoral rally.
